comment.author: 78620024@N07
comment._content: Everything looks so fresh and clean,and the sun is out

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/78620024@N07] The sun is out there big time, look at the reflections on the roof of the Wolseley?  Capel Street was taken into the one way system in 1964 and the traffic went from the bridge up to Bolton Street.  That was changed in the late 80's I think and now it goes down to the bridge from Parnell St.  Goodwins was a good shop with a distinguished clientele and it is great to see that it is still running though the dreadful quality of the neighbouring establishments can hardly help.  McQuillans are still going strong, Louis Copelands father had a small shop on the right close to McQuillans but they later took over the bank which is just past McQuillans in this shot.  At that time a young lad named Eddie Keher worked in that bank.  Capel Street still had several Jewish shops in 1960 but they were down closer to the bridge.  One of them had a dummy or model that they sat at a desk at night with a low light on and you would think that there was a man on guard throughout the night.  If my memory is right this was the street where Sean Lemass was born and raised?

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: McQuillans are still there, too (see streetview link in note above).

comment.author: 30622421@N03
comment._content: This has flipped me back into my childhood!

comment.author: 69751036@N08
comment._content: Slatterys early house, ah the memories of staggering out of there at lunchtime after working a nightshift. Seeing people up ahead crossing to the otherside of the road to avoid you. That was back when I was young - now I have more sense.

comment.author: 16489083@N05
comment._content:
What a marvelous time to have visited Dublin...
oh to roll back the years and retain some of the simpler times!!!
comment.authorname: maorlando God kept us 2012 leaning on Him 2013

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: Those were the days that you had a choice of paraffin (kerosene) for your heater. It was sold in hardware shops and garages. Aladdin Pink, Esso Blue and Fina Green. Television advert - What's got 4 bums and it's blue? "Bum, bum, bum, bum, Esso Blue" www.youtube.com/watch?hl=en&v=-NRbmfLVoWo&gl=US

That one is still going around in my head after ## (censored) years!
